formula:
FACTORIAL:
Let n be a positive integer. Then factorial n is defined as
n! = n(n-1)(n-2)....3.2.1

(i)    0! = 1
(ii)   1! = 1
(iii)  2! = 2 

PERMUTATIONS:
The different ways in which a set or a number of things can be ordered or arranged by taking some or all at a time.

The number of permutations of n things, taken r at a time, is 
nPr = n!/(n-r)!
nP1 = n
nPn = n!

If there are n objects of which 
x1 are of one kind; 
x2 are of another kind; 
x3 of third kind and so on and 
xr of rth kind, such that
x1+x2+x3+...+xr = n
then, permutations of these n objects
= n!/(x1!.x2!.x3!....xr!)

COMBINATIONS:
The different ways of selecting several objects out of a larger group. Unlike permutations, order does not matter here.

The number of all combinations of n things, taken r at a time is
nCr = n!/[r!(n-r)!]

nC1 = n
nCn = 1
nCr = nC(n-r)
nCr = nPr/r!

problems.question: How many 4-digit numbers can be formed from the digits 2, 4, 5, 6, 8 and 9 which are divisible by 5 and none of the digits is repeated?
problems.solution:
For the number to be divisible by 5, the last digit should be 5.

The first 3 digits can be one among 2,4,6,8 and 9.

Number of ways of arranging the first 3 digits
= 5P3
= 5!/2!
= 3*4*5
= 60

problems.question: How many 3-letter words with or without meaning, can be formed out of the letters of the word SUCTION if repetition of letters is not allowed?
problems.solution:
SUCTION contains 7 different letters.

No. of ways of arranging 3 letters out of 7 letters
= 7P3
= 7!/4!
= 210

problems.question: A box contains 2 blue balls, 3 green balls and 4 red balls. In how many ways can 3 balls be drawn from the box, if at least one red ball is to be drawn?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of selecting atleast 1 red ball
= Selecting 3 R 
+ Selecting 2 R and 1 B or G 
+ 1 R and 2 B or G
Ways of selecting 3 Red balls
= 4C3
Ways of selecting 2R and 1 B or G
= 4C2*5C1
Ways of selecting 1R and 2 B or G
= 4C1*5C2
Required no. of ways
= 4C3 + (4C2*5C1) + (4C1*5C2)
= 4+30+40
= 74

problems.question: In how many different ways can the letters of the word LITTLE be arranged?
problems.solution:
The word LITTLE has 6 letters. (2L, 1I, 2T, 1E)

No. of ways 
= 6!/(2!*1!*2!*1!)
= 180

problems.question: There are 10 yes or no questions. In how many ways can these be answered?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of answering 1 question
= 2 (Y,N)

No. of ways of answering 2 question
= 2*2 (YY,YN,NY,NN)

No. of ways of answering 10 questions = 2^10 = 1024

problems.question: In how many ways can the letters of the word POCKET be arranged without changing the positions of the vowels?
problems.solution:
Without changing the positions of the two vowels, only the four consonants P,C,K,T have to be rearranged.

No. of ways of arranging 4 letters
= 4!
= 24

problems.question: In how many ways can the word APTITUDE be arranged such that the vowels always come together?
problems.solution:
The word APTITUDE has 8 letters. (4 vowels, 2 Ts, 1 P and 1 D)

The 4 vowels (A,E,I,U) should always come together. They can be considered as a single letter. So the word can be considered as a 5-letter word.

No. of ways of arranging the 4 vowels
= 4! = 24

No. of ways of arranging a 5-letter word
= 5!

Since there are two Ts, no. of ways
= 5!/2!
= 60

No. of ways of arranging 'APTITUDE' so that vowels dont come together
= 60*24
= 1440

problems.question: Out of 7 consonants and 4 vowels, how many words of 3 consonants and 2 vowels can be formed?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of selecting 3 consonants(out of 7) and 2 vowels(out of 4)
= 7C3 * 4C2
= 35*6
= 210

There are 210 groups, each having 3 consonants and 2 vowels. Each group has 5 letters.

No. of ways of arranging those 5 letters
= 5!
= 120

Required no. of ways 
= 210*120
= 25200

problems.question: From a group consisting of 8 boys and 5 girls, 6 persons are to be selected to form a team so that at least 3 boys are there in the team. In how many ways can this be done?
problems.solution:
The team can consist of 
3 boys, 3 girls
4 boys, 2 girls
5 boys, 1 girl
6 boys

No. of ways 
= (8C3*5C3)+ (8C4*5C2)+ (8C5*5C1)+ (8C6)
= (56*10)+(70*10)+(56*5)+28
= 1568

problems.question: In how many different ways can the letters of the word DENIAL be arranged in such a way that the vowels occupy only the even positions?
problems.solution:
The vowels E,I,A occupy only the even positions.

No. of ways of arranging the 3 vowels in the even positions
= 3!
No of ways of arranging the consonants in the odd positions
= 3!
Required no. of ways
= 3!*3!
= 36

problems.question: You have displayed your five favourite novels between the two ends of your book shelf. If you decide to arrange the five books in every possible combination and move just one book every minute, how long would it take you?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of arranging 5 books
= 5!
= 120
Time taken to arrange
= 120 minutes

problems.question: A school has 10 volleyball players. A team of 5 members and a captain has to be selected out of these 10 players. In how many different ways can the selection be done?
problems.solution:
Out of the 10 players, 6 have to be selected.

Required no. of ways
= 10C6
= 210

problems.question: In a party, there are 50 people. Each person shakes their hand with every other person. How many handshakes take place?
problems.solution:
No. of handshakes
= No. of ways of selecting 2 people out of 50
= 50C2
= 50*49/2
= 1225

problems.question: Find the number of diagonals in an octagon.
problems.solution:
An octagon has 8 vertices.
No. of ways of connecting 2 vertices
= 8C2
= 8*7/2
= 28
Subtracting the 8 sides, 
the no. of diagonals = 28-8 = 20

problems.question: There are 8 seats in a railway compartment - 4 seats facing the engine and the other 4 facing away from the engine. Of the 8 passengers, 3 prefer to face the engine, 3 prefer away and 2 have no preference. In how many ways can the passengers be arranged based on their preferences?
problems.solution:
Of the 4 seats facing the engine,
3 are occupied by the persons who prefer it.
No. of ways of arranging 3 persons in 4 seats = 4!
Of the 4 seats facing away from the engine,
3 are occupied by the persons who prefer it.
No. of ways of arranging 4 persons in 3 seats= 4!
The rest 2 are occupied by the persons who have no preferences. It can be done in 2 ways.

Required no. of ways
= 2*4!*4!
= 1152

problems.question: Find the number of ways in which 11 players can be selected from 15 players if the captain and the vice-captain are always selected.
problems.solution:
The captain and the vice-captain are always selected.

The rest of the 9 players are to be selected from the remaining 13.

No. of ways 
= 13C9
= 13!/(9!*4!)
= 715

problems.question: In how many ways can 5 true or false questions be answered incorrectly?
problems.solution:
5 true or false questions can be answered in 2^5=32 ways.

Only one of these is correct.

No. of ways of answering incorrectly
= 31

problems.question: 8 friends go for a trip in 2 cars. Each car can accomodate a maximum of 4 persons. In how many ways can they travel?
problems.solution:
Required no. of ways
= No. of ways of selecting 4 persons for the first car (since the remaining four will have to travel in the second car)
= 8C4
= 8!/(4!.4!)
= 70

problems.question: A family of 10 people travel in two cars, of which one can seat 6 and the other only 5. In how many ways can they travel?
problems.solution:
They can travel in these ways.
6 people in the first car, 4 people in the second car
5 people in the two cars
Required no. of ways
= 10C6+10C5
= 210+252
= 462

problems.question: In how many ways can the letters of the word EDUCATE be rearranged so that the two Es do not appear together?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of arrangin the letters of EDUCATE (7 letters, 2 Es)
= 7!/2!
= 2520

If EE is taken as a single letter, there would be a total of 6 letters.

No. of ways in which E's appear together
= 6!
= 720
Required no. of ways
= 2520-720
= 1800

problems.question: Find the number of possible ways in which 8 students can be divided into 4 equal teams to take part in an inter-school competition.
problems.solution:
Each team consists of 2 students.

For the first team,
2 students are selected from 8 in
8C2 = 8*7/2 = 28 ways
For the second team,
2 are selected from the remaining 6 in
6C2 = 6*5/2 = 15 ways
For the third team,
2 are selected from the remaining 4 in
4C2 = 6 ways
The remaining 2 will belong to the fourth team.

Total no. of ways
= 28*15*6
= 2520

problems.question: In how many ways can you select four cards, each of a different suit from a standard deck of cards?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of selecting a spade from 13 spades
= 13C1 = 13
No. of ways of selecting a clubs from 13 clubs
= 13 
No. of ways of selecting a hearts from 13 hearts
= 13 
No. of ways of selecting a diamond from 13 diamonds
= 13 
Total no. of ways
= 13*13*13*13
= 28561

problems.question: In how many ways can four cards of different suits having the same value be selected from a standard pack of cards?
problems.solution:
A card can take 13 distinct values.

Since all 4 cards have the same value, only the value has to be selected from the 13 values.

No. of ways of selecting 1 value from 13 values
= 13C1
= 13

problems.question: A committee consisting of 3 men and 4 women is to be formed from a group of 7 men and 8 women. In how many ways can this be done?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of selecting 3 men from 7
= 7C3
= 35
No. of ways of selecting 4 men from 8
= 8C4
= 70
Total no. of ways
= 35*70
= 2450

problems.question: Find the number of triangles in a heptagon.
problems.solution:
There are 7 vertices in a heptagon.

No. of ways of selecting 3 vertices out of 7
= 7C3
= 35

problems.question: In how many ways can 5 letters be posted in 4 postboxes if each postbox can contain any number of letters?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of posting the first letter in any of the 4 postboxes
= 4
Similarly, no. of ways of posting the second letter
= 4
No. of ways of posting the 5 letters
= 4*4*4*4*4
= 1024

problems.question: From a group of 6 men and 8 women, six persons are to be selected to form a committee such that there are at least 2 men and 2 women in the committee. In how many ways can it be done?
problems.solution:
The commitee can consist of
2 men, 4 women
3 men, 3 women
4 men, 2 women
No. of ways
= (6C2*8C4)+(6C3*8C3)+(6C4*8C2)
= (15*70)+(20*56)+(15*28)
= 1050+1120+420
= 2590

problems.question: How many 3 letter words, with or without meaning, can be formed using the letters of the English alphabet without repetition such that the word begins with a vowel and ends with a consonant?
problems.solution:
The first letter is one of the 5 vowels.
No. of ways
= 5

The last letter is one of the 21 consonants.
No. of ways
= 21

The middle letter is selected from the remaining 24 letters.
No. of ways
= 24

Total no. of ways
= 5*21*24
= 2520

problems.question: How many different 4-letter words can be formed using the letters of the word CONSTITUTION such it starts with C and ends with N?
problems.solution:
From the word CONSTITUTION, the 4-letter word
C_ _ N has to be formed.
Leaving out these two letters, we have
2 O, 1 N, 1 S, 3 T, 2 I, 1 U

3 unique letters - N S U
3 duplicate letters - O T I

If our second letter is either of N,S or U
we have 5 choices for the third letter.
Eg: NS, NU, NO, NT, NI

If our second letter is either O, T or I
we have 6 choices for the third letter.
Eg: ON, OS, OU, OO, OT, OI

No. of ways
= (3*5)+(3*6)
= 33

problems.question: An organisation has 3 committees, only 2 persons are members of all 3 committees but every pair of committees has 3 members in common. What is the least possible number of members in any one committee?
problems.solution:
Let A and B be the 2 persons who are members of all committees.

Every pair of committees has 3 members in common.
Let A, B and C be common to I and II.
Let A, B and D be common to II and III.
Let A, B and E be common to III and I.

I   - A, B, C, E
II  - A, B, C, D
III - A, B, D, E

Hence, the least possible number of members is 4.

problems.question: A student can select one of 6 different math books, one of 3 different chemistry books & one of 4 different science books. In how many different ways can students select one book each of math, chemistry & science?
problems.solution:
No. of different ways
= 6C1*3C1*4C1
= 6*3*4
= 72

problems.question: 4 women and 6 men have to be seated in a row given that no two women can sit together. How many different arrangements are possible?
problems.solution:
The 6 men can be seated in 6! ways.

The women have to be seated in between the men or at the corners.
_ M _ M _ M _ M _ M _ M _

There are 7 possible seats for them.

No. of ways in which 4 women can occupy 7 seats
= 7P4

Total no. of ways
= 6!*7P4

problems.question: In how many ways can a team of 11 members be selected from a team of 5 men and 11 women such that the team must comprise of not more than 3 men?
A owes B Rs.50. He agrees to pay B over a number of consecutive days on a Monday, paying a single note or Rs.10 or Rs.20 on each day.In how many different ways can A repay B?
problems.solution:
Rs.10 on all days
1 way
Rs.10 on 4 days, Rs.20 on 1 day
4 ways
Rs.10 on 1 day, Rs.20 on 2 days
3 ways
Total = 8 ways

problems.question: Find the total number of combinations of 5 letters a,b,a,b,b taking some or all at a time.
problems.solution:
a,b,a,b,b

1 letter can be chosen in 2 ways
a , b
2 letters can be chosen in 3 ways
aa, ab, bb
3 letters can be chosen in 3 ways
aab, abb, bbb 
4 letters can be chosen in 2 ways
aabb, abbb
5 letters can be chosen in 1 way

Total ways = 11

problems.question: The total number of 4 digit numbers which do not have the digits 3 or 6 is
problems.solution:
The first digit cant be 0, 3 or 6.
Hence, it can take 7 other values.
The other three digits cant be 3 or 6.
Hence, they can take 8 other values.

Hence, total no. of such 4 digit numbers
= 7*8*8*8
= 3584

problems.question: In how many ways can we distribute 10 pencils to 4 children so that each child gets atleast one pencil?
problems.solution:
No. of ways of distributing r identical objects to n distinct objects so that each get atleast one
= (n-1)C(r-1)
= 9C3
= 84

problems.question: In how many different ways can the letters of the word LEADING be arranged in such a way that the vowels always come together?
problems.solution:
There are three vowels and four consonants. The vowels should always come together. So, they can be considered as a letter.

No. of ways of arranging 5 letters
= 5!
No. of ways of arranging the vowels
= 3!
Total no. of ways
= 5!*3!
= 720

problems.question: Find the number of ways a batsman can score a century only in terms of both 4's & 6's.
problems.solution:
Let the batsman score x fours and y sixes.

4x+6y = 100
2x+3y=50

x = (50-3y)/2

50-3y should be a multiple of 2.
Hence, y should be even.

y=0, x=25
y=2, x=22
y=4, x=19
.....
.....
y=16, x=1

Since he should get both 4s and 6s, 0 sixes is not possible.

No. of ways = 8

problems.question: The letters in the word WRITING are permuted in all possible ways and arranged in alphabetical order. Find the word at position 50 in the permuted alphabetical order.
problems.solution:
Arranging the letters of WRITING in alphabetical order,
G,I,I,N,R,T,W

G _ _ _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with G
= 6!/2!
= 360 ways
The 50th word starts with G.

GI _ _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with GI
= 5! = 120

G I I _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with GII
= 4! = 24

G I N _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with GIN
= 4!
= 24

24+24 = 48

The 50th word will be the second word starting with GIR.

49th word - GIRINTW
50th word - GIRINWT

problems.question: A white cube(with six faces) is painted red on two different faces.How many different ways can this be done (two paintings are considered same if on a suitable rotation of the cube one painting can be carried to the other)?
problems.solution:
This can be done only in two ways.

1. Painting two opposite faces
2. Painting two adjacent faces

problems.question: A manufacturer of chocolates makes 6 different flavors of chocolates. The chocolates are sold in boxes of 10. How many "different" boxes of chocolates can be made?
problems.solution:
If n similar articles are to be distributed to r persons, x1+x2+x3......xr=n each person is eligible to take any number of articles then the total ways are
(n+r-1) C r-1

Here, n=10 and r=6

15C5 = 15*14*13*12*11/(1*2*3*4*5)
          = 3003

problems.question: How many different 9 digit numbers can be formed from the number 223355888 by re-arranging its digits so that the odd digits occupy the even positions?
problems.solution:
There are 4 even places and they are occupied by the 4 odd digits (3,3,5,5)

No. of ways
= 4!/(2!*2!)
= 6

The 5 even numbers should occupy the 5 odd places. (2,2,8,8,8)

No. of ways
= 5!/(2!*3!)
= 10

Total no. of ways
= 10*6 = 60

problems.question: The letters in the word ADOPTS are permuted in all possible ways and arranged in alphabetical order then find the word at position 42 in the permuted alphabetical order?
problems.solution:
Arranging the letters of ADOPTS in alphabetical order,
A,D,O,P,S,T

A  _ _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with A
= 5!
= 120 ways
The 42nd word starts with A.

AD _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with AD
= 4! = 24

A O _ _ _ _
No. of words starting with AO
= 4! = 24

The 42nd word starts with AO.

No. of words starting with AOD
= 6
No. of words starting with AOP
= 6
No. of words starting with AOS
= 6
24+6+6+6=42

The 42nd word is the last word starting with AOS

AOSTPD

problems.question: Bill purchases an item and receives no change. Before the purchase, he had only a five dollar bill, two ten-dollar bills, and a twenty-dollar bill. How many distinct possibilities are there for the total amount of his purchase?

Meg and Bob are among the 5 participants in a cycling race. If each participant finishes the race and no two participants finish at the same time, in how many different possible orders can the participants finish the race so that Meg finishes ahead of Bob?
problems.solution:
Case (i)
Meg finishes first. The other 4 can take any of the other places.
No. of ways = 4! = 24

Case (ii)
Meg finishes second. Bob has to be either third, fourth or fifth. The other 3 can take any of the 3 other places.
No. of ways = 3*3! = 18

Case (iii)
Meg finishes 3rd. Bob has to be 4th or 5th. Others can take any of the remaining 3 places.
No. of ways = 2*3! = 12

Case (iv)
Meg finishes 4th. Bob finishes 5th. Others can take the 3 other places.
No. of ways = 3! = 6

Total no. of ways
= 24+18+12+6
= 60

problems.question: Sixty-eight people are sitting in 20 cars and each car contains at most 4 people. What is the maximum possible number of cars that could contain exactly 1 of the 68 people?
problems.solution: 16 cars contain 4 people each and 4 cars contain 1 person each.

problems.question: A gardener wishes to plant 5 bushes in a straight row. Each bush has flowers of a different solid color (white, yellow, pink, red and purple). How many ways can the bushes be arranged so that the middle bush is the one with red flowers?
problems.solution: The middle bush is red. The other 4 bushes can be arrranged in 4! = 24 ways.

problems.question: There are 20 balls of green color, 20 of red color, 20 of blue color, 20 of black and 20 of yellow. Howmany balls do you have to pick to guarantee 2 pairs of same color?
problems.solution: The first 5 balls may be one of each color. The 6th ball will definitely form a pair with any one of the five.

problems.question: If x is 1, 2, or 3 and y is either 2 or 4, then the product xy can have how many different possible values?
problems.solution:
Possible values of xy
= 2,4,8,6,12

problems.question: A lady has fine gloves and hats in her closet- 18 blue, 33 red, and 25 yellow. The lights are out and it is totally dark. In spite of the darkness, she can make out the difference between a hat and a glove. She takes out an item out of the closet only if she is sure that it is a glove. How many gloves must she take out to make sure she has a pair of each color?
problems.solution:
She has to take 60 gloves to ensure she has a pair of each color.

First 33 may be red.

The next 25 may be yellow.

The next 2 may be blue.

problems.question: 36 people {a1, a2... a36} meet and shake hands in a circular fashion. In other words, there are totally 36 handshakes involving the pairs, {a1, a2}, {a2, a3}, ..., {a35, a36}, {a36, a1}. Then the size of the smallest set of people such that the rest have shaken hands with at least one person in the set is

It is dark in my bedroom and I want to get two socks of the same color from my drawer, which contains 24 red and 24 blue socks. How many socks do I have to take from the drawer to get at least two socks of the same color?
problems.solution: The first two socks may be one each of red and blue. The third will definitely make a pair with either of the two.

problems.question: 23 people are there, they are shaking hands together, how many hand shakes are possible, if they are in pairs of cyclic sequence?
problems.solution:
If there are three persons and they shake hands in cyclic manner,
(a,b), (b,c), (c,a)

Similarly, if there are 23 persons,
23 handshakes are possible.

problems.question: The thanksgiving banquet at No.2, Richter Street, had 49 guests which consisted of 6 statesmen, 26 relatives and their families. At the end of a banquet 25 people shake hands with other, some of which were between the statesmen alone, some between relatives alone and some between the statesmen and relatives. How many handshakes will there be in total?
problems.solution:
No. of handshakes
= 25C2
= 300

problems.question: 3 kinds of pizzas were available in a Pizza Shop. But, now they have introduced 7 new types. A person wants to buy three different types of pizzas with at least 1 in the new type. In how many ways can he select?
problems.solution:
He should not select
3 from old

No. of ways of selecting 3 from old
= 1
No. of ways
= 10C3 - 1
= 120-1
= 119

problems.question: There are 7 friends (A1, A2, A3....A7). If A1 has to shake hands with all without repetition, how many handshakes are possible?
problems.solution:
A1 will shake hands with A2,A3,A4,A5,A6,A7.

6 handshakes.

problems.question: SSCT Consultancy Services wanted to select 78 candidates from the five engineering Colleges in Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Karnataka. They wanted only those candidates who have cleared all papers in semester exams to appear for their recruitment test. The test paper set by them consisted of two parts- Part I and Part II. Each part consisted of 7 questions and the candidates are supposed to answer only six questions. Candidates were given the freedom to choose any 6 questions across Part I and Part II but with a simple condition that at least one question should be answered from part I. In how many ways a candidate can attempt this paper assuming he answers six questions?
problems.solution:
The candidates can choose
1 from A, 5 from B
2 from A, 4 from B
3 from A, 3 from B
4 from A, 2 from B
5 from A, 1 from B
6 from A, 0 from B

No. of ways
= (7C1*7C5)+(7C2*7C4)+(7C3*7C3)+(7C4*7C2)+(7C5*7C1)+(7C6)
= 147+735+1225+735+147+7
= 2996

problems.question: In how many ways can a leap year have 53 Sundays?
problems.solution:
In a leap year there are 366 days. (52 weeks + 2 extra days)

To have 53 Sundays,
one of the two extra days must be a Sunday. 

This can occur in only 2 ways.
(Saturday and Sunday) or (Sunday and Monday)

Number of ways =2

problems.question: There are 4 books on fairy tales, 5 novels and 3 plays. In how many ways can you arrange these so that books on fairy tales are together, novels are together and plays are together and in the order, books on fairy tales, novels and plays?
problems.solution:
The books on fairy tales can be arranged in 4! = 24 ways
The books on novels can be arranged in 5! = 120 ways
The books on plays can be arranged in 3! = 6 ways

They have to be arranged in the order
Fairy Tales, Novels, Play

Total Number of ways
= 24*120*6
= 17280

problems.question: A teacher of 6 students takes 2 of his students at a time to a zoo as often as he can, without taking the same pair of children together more than once. How many times does the teacher go to the zoo?
problems.solution:
Two students can be selected from 6 in 6C2 ways.

6C2 = 6*5/2 = 15

Therefore, the teacher goes 15 times to the zoo.

problems.question: How many four letter distinct initials can be formed using the alphabets of English language such that the last of the four letters is always a consonant?
problems.solution:
The last of the four letters should be a consonant. Therefore, there are 21 options for the last letter.

The first three letters can be either consonants or vowels. So, each letter has 26 options. 

We are asked to find out the number of distinct initials and not initials where the letters are distinct. Hence, the letters can be repeated in an initial.

Number of distinct initials
= 26*26*26*21
= 26³*21

problems.question: A box contains 10 balls out of which 3 are red and the rest are blue. In how many ways can a random sample of 6 balls be drawn from the bag so that at the most 2 red balls are included in the sample and no sample has all the 6 balls of the same colour?
problems.solution:
There are 3 red balls and 7 blue balls.

Given the conditions, 6 balls can be selected in the following ways.

(i) One red ball and 5 blue balls
(ii) Two red balls and 4 blue balls

Total number of ways
= 3C1*7C5 + 3C2*7C4
= 63 + 105
= 168

problems.question: There are 6 equally spaced points A,B,C,D,E and F marked on a circle with radius R. How many convex pentagons of distinctly different areas can be drawn using these points as vertices?
problems.solution: All the points are equally spaced. Hence, the area of all the convex pentagons will be the same.

problems.question: A man is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system. The man can take steps of unit measure in the direction North, East, West or South. Find the number of ways in which he can reach the point (5,6), covering the shortest possible distance.
problems.solution:
In order to reach (5,6) covering the shortest distance at the same time, the man has to make 5 horizontal and 6 vertical steps.

The number of ways in which these steps can be taken
= 11! / (5!*6!)
= 462

problems.question: Find thetotalnumberofdistinctvehiclenumbersthatcanbeformedusingtwo letters followed by two numbers. Letters need to be distinct.
problems.solution:
Choosing two Letters:
Out of 26 alphabets, two distinct letters can be chosen in 26P2 ways.
 
Choosing two Numbers:
There are 10 ways (any number from 0 to 9) to choose the first digit and similarly, another 10 ways to choose the second digit.
Hence the two numbers can be chosen in 10*10 = 100 ways. (00 to 99)

Total Number of ways
= 26P2*100
= 65000

problems.question: In how many ways a President, VP and Waterboy can be selected from a group of 10 people?
problems.solution:
We are selecting three different posts, so order matters.

Number of ways of selecting a President, VP and Waterboy from a group of 10 people
= 10P3

problems.question: How many words can be formed by re-arranging the letters of the word ASCENT such that A and T occupy the first and last position respectively?
problems.solution:
A and T should occupy the first and last position.

A _ _ _ _ T

The remaining 4 positions can be filled in
4! ways by the remaining letters (S,C,E,N,T). 

4! words can be formed.

problems.question: A class photograph has to be taken. The front row consists of 6 girls who are sitting. 20 boys are standing behind. The two corner positions are reserved for the 2 tallest boys. In how many ways can the students be arranged?
problems.solution:
The two tallest boys can be arranged in 2! ways, rest 18 can be arranged in 18! ways.

Girls can be arranged in 6! ways.

Total number of ways in which all the students can be arranged
= 2!* 18! * 6!
= 18! * 2 * 720 
= 18! * 1440

problems.question: In how many different ways can the letters of the word OPTICAL be arranged so that the vowels always come together?
problems.solution:
The word OPTICAL contains 7 different letters.

The three vowels O,I,A should come together. Hence, they can be considered as a single letter.

We have to arrange the letters PTCL (OIA).

5 letters can be arranged in 5! = 120 ways.

The vowels (OIA) can be arranged among themselves in 3! = 6 ways.

Required number of ways
= (120 x 6)
= 720
